verse: When they had gotten close to Jerusalem, near the two villages of Bethphage and Bethany and the Mount of Olives, Jesus sent two of His followers ahead of them.
Everything happened just as Jesus had told them. They found the colt in the street tied near a door, and they untied it.
They answered as Jesus had instructed and were allowed to take it,
so they brought the colt back to Jesus, piled garments on its back to make a comfortable seat, and Jesus rode the animal toward Jerusalem.
As they traveled, people cast their cloaks onto the road and spread out leafy branches, which they had brought from the fields along the way.
People walked ahead of them, and others followed behind.

To the sound of this chanting, Jesus rode through the gates of Jerusalem and up to the temple. He looked around and saw that evening was coming, so He and the twelve went back to Bethany to spend the night.
The next morning, when they departed Bethany and were traveling back to the city, Jesus was hungry.

Off in the distance, He saw a fig tree fully leafed out, so He headed toward it to see if it might have any ripe fruit. But when He reached it, He found only leaves because the fig season had not yet come.
As the disciples listened, Jesus pronounced a curse on the tree.
They continued into Jerusalem and made their way up to the temple.
and He physically prevented anyone from carrying anything through the temple.

The chief priests and the scribes heard these words and knew Jesus was referring to them, so they plotted His destruction. They had grown afraid of Him because His teachings struck the crowds into astonishment.
When evening came, [Jesus and His followers] left the city again.
The next morning on the way back to Jerusalem, they passed a tree that had withered down to its very roots.
As they arrived in Jerusalem and were walking in the temple, the chief priests, scribes, and elders came to Jesus
The priests, scribes, and elders huddled together to think through an answer.
